_**Cape Fear**_ is a 1962 American [psychological
thriller](/wiki/Psychological_thriller "Psychological thriller") film starring
[Robert Mitchum](/wiki/Robert_Mitchum "Robert Mitchum"), [Gregory
Peck](/wiki/Gregory_Peck "Gregory Peck"), [Martin Balsam](/wiki/Martin_Balsam
"Martin Balsam"), and [Polly Bergen](/wiki/Polly_Bergen "Polly Bergen"). It
was adapted by [James R. Webb](/wiki/James_R._Webb_\(writer\) "James R. Webb
\(writer\)") from the novel _[The
Executioners](/wiki/The_Executioners_\(MacDonald_novel\) "The Executioners
\(MacDonald novel\)")_ by [John D. MacDonald](/wiki/John_D._MacDonald "John D.
MacDonald"). It was initially storyboarded by [Alfred
Hitchcock](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock "Alfred Hitchcock") (slated to direct but
quit over a dispute), subsequently directed by [J. Lee
Thompson](/wiki/J._Lee_Thompson "J. Lee Thompson"), and released on April 12,
1962. The movie concerns an attorney whose family is stalked by a criminal he
helped to send to jail.

_Cape Fear_ was [remade in 1991](/wiki/Cape_Fear_\(1991_film\) "Cape Fear
\(1991 film\)") by [Martin Scorsese](/wiki/Martin_Scorsese "Martin Scorsese").
Peck, Mitchum, and Balsam all appeared in the remake.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

After spending eight years in prison for [rape](/wiki/Rape "Rape"), [Max
Cady](/wiki/Max_Cady "Max Cady") ([Robert Mitchum](/wiki/Robert_Mitchum
"Robert Mitchum")) is released. He promptly tracks down Sam Bowden ([Gregory
Peck](/wiki/Gregory_Peck "Gregory Peck")), a lawyer whom he holds personally
responsible for his conviction because Sam interrupted his attack and
testified against him. Cady begins to stalk and subtly threaten Bowden's
family. He kills the Bowden family dog, though Sam cannot prove Cady did it. A
friend of Bowden's, police chief Mark Dutton ([Martin
Balsam](/wiki/Martin_Balsam "Martin Balsam")), attempts to intervene on
Bowden's behalf, but he cannot prove Cady guilty of any crime.

Bowden hires [private detective](/wiki/Private_detective "Private detective")
Charlie Sievers ([Telly Savalas](/wiki/Telly_Savalas "Telly Savalas")). Cady
brutally attacks a promiscuous young woman named Diane Taylor ([Barrie
Chase](/wiki/Barrie_Chase "Barrie Chase")) when she brings him home, but
neither the private eye nor Bowden can persuade her to testify. Bowden hires
three thugs to beat up Cady and persuade him to leave town, but the plan
backfires when Cady gets the better of all three. Cady's lawyer vows to have
Bowden [disbarred](/wiki/Disbar "Disbar").

Afraid for his wife Peggy ([Polly Bergen](/wiki/Polly_Bergen "Polly Bergen"))
and 14-year-old daughter Nancy ([Lori Martin](/wiki/Lori_Martin "Lori
Martin")), Bowden takes them to their houseboat in [Cape
Fear](/wiki/Cape_Fear_\(region\) "Cape Fear \(region\)"). In an attempt to
trick Cady, Bowden makes it seem as though he has gone to a completely
different location. He fully expects Cady to follow his wife and daughter, and
he plans on killing Cady to end the battle. Bowden and a local deputy hide
nearby, but Cady realizes the deputy is there and kills him. Eluding Bowden,
Cady first attacks Mrs. Bowden on the boat, causing Bowden to go to her
rescue. Meanwhile, Cady swims back to shore to attack Nancy. Bowden realizes
what has happened, and also swims ashore.

The two men engage in a final violent fight on the riverbank. Bowden
overpowers Cady, but decides not to kill him, preferring to let him spend the
rest of his life in jail. The film ends with the Bowden family sitting
together on a boat the next morning.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Casting")]

[Rod Steiger](/wiki/Rod_Steiger "Rod Steiger") wanted to play Max Cady, but he
backed off when he heard Mitchum was considering the role.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Telly
Savalas was screentested for the role, but later played private eye Charlie
Sievers.[1]

[Charles Bronson](/wiki/Charles_Bronson "Charles Bronson"), [James
Coburn](/wiki/James_Coburn "James Coburn"), [Charlton
Heston](/wiki/Charlton_Heston "Charlton Heston"), [Jack
Palance](/wiki/Jack_Palance "Jack Palance"), and [John Wayne](/wiki/John_Wayne
"John Wayne"), were all considered for the role of the attorney, Sam
Bowden.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Peck was a last-minute replacement for Heston, who was originally
cast.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

[Jim Backus](/wiki/Jim_Backus "Jim Backus") was set to play attorney Dave
Grafton.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Filming")]

Thompson had always envisioned the film in black and white prior to
production. As an [Alfred Hitchcock](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock "Alfred
Hitchcock") fan, he wanted to have [Hitchcockian](/wiki/Hitchcockian
"Hitchcockian") elements in the film, such as unusual lighting angles, an
eerie musical score, closeups, and subtle hints rather than graphic depictions
of the violence Cady has in mind for the family.

The outdoor scenes were filmed on location in [Savannah,
Georgia](/wiki/Savannah,_Georgia "Savannah, Georgia"), [Stockton,
California](/wiki/Stockton,_California "Stockton, California"), and the
Universal Studios backlot at [Universal City,
California](/wiki/Universal_City,_California "Universal City, California").
The indoor scenes were done at Universal Studios Soundstage. Mitchum had a
real-life aversion to Savannah, where as a teenager, he had been charged with
vagrancy and put on a [chain gang](/wiki/Chain_gang "Chain gang"). This
resulted in a number of the outdoor scenes' being shot at Ladd's Marina in
Stockton, including the culminating conflict on the houseboat at the end of
the movie.

This scene where Mitchum attacks Polly Bergen's character on the houseboat was
almost completely improvised.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Before
the scene was filmed, Thompson suddenly told a crew member: "Bring me a dish
of eggs!" Mitchum's rubbing the eggs on Bergen was not scripted and Bergen's
reactions were real. She also suffered back injuries from being knocked around
so much. She felt the impact of the "attack" for days.[2] While filming the
scene, Mitchum cut open his hand, leading Bergen to recall: "his hand was
covered in blood, my back was covered in blood. We just kept going, caught up
in the scene. They came over and physically stopped us."[3]

In the source novel _[The
Executioners](/wiki/The_Executioners_\(MacDonald_novel\) "The Executioners
\(MacDonald novel\)")_ , by [John D. MacDonald](/wiki/John_D._MacDonald "John
D. MacDonald"), Cady was a soldier [court-martialed](/wiki/Court-martial
"Court-martial") and convicted on then Lieutenant Bowden's testimony for the
brutal rape of a 14-year-old girl. The censors stepped in, banned the use of
the word "rape", and stated that depicting Cady as a soldier reflected
adversely on U.S. military personnel.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Music")]

[Bernard Herrmann](/wiki/Bernard_Herrmann "Bernard Herrmann"), as often in his
scores, uses a reduced version of the symphony orchestra. Here, other than a
46-piece string section (slightly larger than usual for film scores), he adds
four [flutes](/wiki/Flutes "Flutes") (doubling on two
[piccolos](/wiki/Piccolos "Piccolos"), two [alto flutes](/wiki/Alto_flute
"Alto flute") in G, and two [bass flutes](/wiki/Bass_flute "Bass flute") in C)
and eight [French horns](/wiki/French_horn "French horn"). No use is made of
further wind instruments or percussion.[4]

In his 2002 book _A Heart at Fire 's Center: The Life and Music of Bernard
Herrmann_, Stephen C. Smith writes:

> "Yet Herrmann was perfect for _Cape Fear_ ... Herrmann's score reinforces
> _Cape Fear 's_ savagery. Mainly a synthesis of past devices, its power comes
> from their imaginative application and another ingenious orchestration ... a
> rehearsal for his similar orchestration on Hitchcock's _[Torn
> Curtain](/wiki/Torn_Curtain "Torn Curtain")_ in 1966. Like similar
> "psychological" Herrmann scores, dissonant string combinations suggest the
> workings of a killer's mind (most startlingly in a queasy device for
> [cello](/wiki/Cello "Cello") and [bass viols](/wiki/Bass_viol "Bass viol")
> as Cadey prepares to attack the prostitute). Hermann's prelude searingly
> establishes the dramatic conflict: descending and ascending chromatic voices
> move slowly towards each other from their opposite registers, finally
> crossing–just as Bodens and Cadey's game of cat-and-mouse will end in deadly
> confrontation."[5]

##
Distribution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Distribution")]

Although the word "rape" was entirely removed from the script before shooting,
the film still enraged the censors, who worried that "there was a continuous
threat of sexual assault on a child." To accept the film, British censors
required extensive editing and deleting of specific scenes. After making
around 6 minutes of cuts, the film still nearly garnered a British X rating
(meaning at the time, "Suitable for those aged 18 and older", not necessarily
meaning there was sexually explicit or violent content).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Home media")]

_Cape Fear_ was first made available on VHS on March 1, 1992. It was later re-
released on VHS, as well as DVD, on September 18, 2001. The film was released
onto [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-ray") on January 8, 2013. It contains
production photos and a "making-of" featurette.[6]

##
Reaction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Reaction")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Critical response")]

Upon its release, the film received positive but cautious feedback from
critics due to the film's content. Review aggregator [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") reports that 95% of 20
critics have given the film a positive review, with a rating average of 7.6
out of 10.[7]

[Bosley Crowther](/wiki/Bosley_Crowther "Bosley Crowther") of the _[New York
Times](/wiki/New_York_Times "New York Times")_ praised the "tough, tight
script", as well as the film's "steady and starkly sinister style." He went on
to conclude his review by saying, "this is really one of those shockers that
provokes disgust and regret."[8] The entertainment-[trade
magazine](/wiki/Trade_journal "Trade journal")
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ reviewed the
film as "competent and visually polished", while commenting on Mitchum's
performance as a "menacing omnipresence."[9]

###
Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Fear_\(1962_film\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Legacy")]

Although it makes no acknowledgement of _Cape Fear_ , the episode "The Force
of Evil" from the 1977 [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") television series _[Quinn
Martin's Tales of the
Unexpected](/wiki/Quinn_Martin%27s_Tales_of_the_Unexpected "Quinn Martin's
Tales of the Unexpected")_ uses virtually the same plot, merely introducing an
additional supernatural element to the released prisoner.[10][11]

The film and [its remake](/wiki/Cape_Fear_\(1991_film\) "Cape Fear \(1991
film\)") serve as the basis for the 1993 _[The Simpsons](/wiki/The_Simpsons
"The Simpsons")_ episode "[Cape Feare](/wiki/Cape_Feare "Cape Feare")" in
which [Sideshow Bob](/wiki/Sideshow_Bob "Sideshow Bob"), recently released
from prison, stalks the Simpson family in an attempt to kill Bart.

In April 2007, _[Newsweek](/wiki/Newsweek "Newsweek")_ selected Cady as one of
the 10 best villains in cinema history. Specifically, the scene where Cady
attacks Sam's family was ranked number 36 on
[Bravo](/wiki/Bravo_\(US_TV_channel\) "Bravo \(US TV channel\)")'s _[100
Scariest Movie Moments](/wiki/The_100_Scariest_Movie_Moments "The 100 Scariest
Movie Moments")_ in 2004.[12]

A consumer poll on the [Internet Movie Database](/wiki/Internet_Movie_Database
"Internet Movie Database") rates _Cape Fear_ as the 65th-best trial film,
although the trial scenes are merely incidental to the plot.[13]

The film is recognized by [American Film
Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute") in these
lists:

  * 2001: [AFI's 100 Years...100 Thrills](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Thrills "AFI's 100 Years...100 Thrills") – #61[14]
  * 2003: [AFI's 100 Years...100 Heroes & Villains](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Heroes_%26_Villains "AFI's 100 Years...100 Heroes & Villains"): 
    * [Max Cady](/wiki/Max_Cady "Max Cady") – #28 Villain[15]
